div1.p: This document provides a brief overview of Agramonte in terms of his family, public offices in the U.S., professional memberships, and original articles published.

div1.head: Curriculum Vitae of Aristides Agramonte, [19--]
div1.p: DR. ARISTIDES AGRAMONTE, born in Puerto Principe, Cuba, June 3, 1868.-

His father was the insurgent Gen. Eduardo Agramonte, killed
in battle March 8th, 1872.

His family emigrated to the United States where he obtained his
education, first in the public schools, then in the Col-
lege of the City of New York and finally in the Col. of
Physicians and Surgeons, (Columbia College,) where he
he graduated with honor (Third Harsen Prize,) June 8th,
1892.

list.head: PUBLIC OFFICES in the United States.
list.item:
Visiting Physician, (Diseases of Children,) West Side German
Dispensary, 1894 to 1898.

Visiting Physician, (Department Diseases of Children,) Belle-
vue Hosp. Dispensary, 1895 to 1898.

Sanitary Inspector, (New York Department of Health,) after
Civil Service examination with a rating of 99.20 %, 1896.

Assistant Bacteriologist, (New York Department of Health,)
after Civil Service examination with a rating of 93.40 %,
from 1896, (dec.) to May 1, 1898.

item.p:
Acting Assistant Surgeon, U. S. Army, from May 1, 1898 to Aug.
15th, 1902.

As an Act'g Ass't Surgeon he was sent to Santiago in July 1898
returning to Washington in November; after presenting a
report of investigations made at Santiago he was sent to Havana in
Decembre 1898 where he carried out further investigations,
published in the Medical News, February, 1900.

list.item:
In May 1900 he was appointed in charge of Army Laboratory of
the Division of Cuba which he reatained till the end of
his service.

Appointed May 1900 a member of the Board of Medical Officers
“to investigate the infectious diseases prevalent in the
Island of Cuba,” with Maj. Walter Reed, and Drs. James
Carroll and Jesse W. Lazear.

He investigated an epidemic of Yellow fever in Santa Clara,
Cuba, by Special Orders, June 27, 1900.

He investigated the “exact nature of certain cases of perni-
cious fever reported to have occured,” at Pinar del Rio,
Cuba, (Special Orders of July 17, 1900,) and found that
there was an epidemic of yellow fever in a garrison of
eight hundred troops unknown to the medical officers who
had been treating the cases as malarial fevers. For this
work and his stand in the face of the natural oposition
presented by the medical officers in charge, Dr. Agramon-
te was publicly complimented by the Commanding Officer.

In August 1900 he passed incorporation examinations before the
Medical Faculty of the University of Havana and sub-
sequently obtained the Degree of M.D. from said Faculty.

In Septembre 1900 he obtained by competitive examination, the
Chair of Bacteriology and Experimental Pathology in the
University of Havana
